article:
Steve Kimhall started a career in March as a school-bus driver for First Student Norwich.
         The morning of April 8 seemed   _  , Kimball recalled,
except that he didn't quite feel right. Noah got in the bus and noticed
immediately that the driver didn't  _  well; he
wasn't talking and joking  the way  the two of them are
used to doing every morning.
         Throughout the brief ride to   pick up  more riders, Noah kept
asking Kimball, "Steve, are you all right?"
         Kimball said the boy' s persistence was getting him annoyed. So Noah   _  sent a quick text message to his parents  _  the
driver was definitely sick but  _  he was OK. His
father  _  the bus company immediately. It wasn't
long  _  the ambulance came over and drove
Kimball to the nearest hospital.
         "The doctor said I   _  a severe heart attack," Kimball
said Thursday,  _  recovering at his Norwich home. Kimball said. "God worked a miracle in Noah. He saved my life, plain and
simple."
         Kimball wasn't the only one   _  . On Tuesday, First Student
held a ceremony at Noah' s school  in honor of  him for his
"heroic leadership." Company officials  _  him
with a plaque and a $50 prize.
         "You are being   _  for your quick thinking and showing
great care and  _  for your driver, and because
of you, he will be just fine," the plaque  _  .
         Noah doesn't care for the sudden   _  . He had to be coaxed by Kimball to attend Tuesday's ceremony." I just did what was the right   _  to do," he said.
         But Noah wasn't shy when asked whether he was   looking forward to  Steve's
return to work.
         "Oh, yeah!" he said.
